{{refimprove|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox organization |name = Rocky Mountain Mineral Law Foundation |bgcolor = |fgcolor = |image = RMMLF_Logo_2016.jpg |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |map2 = |abbreviation = RMMLF |motto = |predecessor = |successor = |formation = 1955 |extinction = |type = [[501(c) organization|501(c)(3)]] |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Westminster, Colorado|Westminster]], [[Colorado]], [[United States]] |location = |coords = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> |region_served = Global |membership = |language = |general = |leader_title = President |leader_name = Michael J. Malmquist |leader_title2 = Vice President |leader_name2 = William B. Prince |leader_title3 = Executive Director |leader_name3 = Alex Ritchie |leader_title4 = |leader_name4 = |key_people = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |budget = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |website = {{URL|rmmlf.org}} |remarks = |former name = }} The '''Rocky Mountain Mineral Law Foundation''' ('''RMMLF''') is a collaborative, educational [[nonprofit organization]] dedicated to the scholarly and practical study of the law and regulations relating to mining, [[oil and gas]], energy, water, public lands, and related areas.<ref name="rmmlf">{{cite web|title=RMMLF website|url=https://www.rmmlf.org/default.htm}}</ref>
The Foundation is governed by a [[Board of Directors]] and guided by a [[Trustees]] Council that includes representatives from constituent law schools,<ref>E.g., Washburn University School of Law, Student Organizations, http://washburnlaw.edu/students/organizations/</ref> bar associations, and mining and oil and gas associations.<ref>''See'' Denver University, Sturm College of Law website, http://www.law.du.edu/index.php/enrgp/research-sources</ref> Leading legal, land, and other experts work as volunteers to the Foundation and its committees.
Through educational programs, the Foundation brings together lawyers, landmen, managers, government personnel, law faculty, students, and others involved in mineral, oil & gas, water, and other resources.
==History== The Foundation was organized in 1955 to provide broad educational coverage over a wide geographic area to many practitioners and mineral company personnel who were interested in a field of law in which only a few were expert, and to avoid duplication of effort among the law schools and industry organizations interested in the problems of the rapidly developing mineral industry, particularly the oil and gas industry in the Rocky Mountain area. The first institute brought mineral resources lawyers together to hear experts talk on significant and timely subjects. The papers from the conference provided permanent reference material, which was made available by publication of the Proceedings of the First Annual Institute. The Foundation has continued to be a meeting place and focal point for lawyers and others whose work brings them into contact with the legal aspects mining, oil and gas, energy, water, public lands, and related areas.
When the decline of the oil and gas industry occurred in the Rocky Mountain area in the early 1960s, it was accompanied by increased activity in "hard rock" minerals. Commencing around 1965, the Foundation gave increasing attention to mining law and to expansion into water law, as well as expanding geographically into new areas of the west. This policy was put into effect in 1967 by adding to the Annual Institutes a section for water lawyers, an innovation that has continued to the present time. The geographic expansion might be considered as beginning with the 14th Annual Institute at Flagstaff, Arizona in 1968, which also inaugurated a Landman's Section that has since been a regular feature of the Annual Institute.<ref>Victor H. Verity, "A Mini-View of the Past 25 Years," 25 ''Rocky Mt. Min. L. Inst.'' at xxxi (1979).</ref>
The Foundation began a new era with the appointment of David P. Phillips as Executive Director in December 1970. The regions served have gradually expanded past the Rocky Mountains under the direction of Mr. Phillips, first to Canada and Mexico and then later to South America.<ref>John C. Lacy, "The Second Twenty-Five Years, A History of the Rocky Mountain Mineral Law Institute 1979-2004," 50 ''Rocky Mt. Min. L. Inst.'' at xix (2004).</ref> The Foundation today is a tribute to the foresight of its founders, who created a structure with a balance that has accommodated diverse opinions.
==Programs== In fulfilling its goals, the Foundation carries out varied programs of interest to attorneys, landmen, management, government personnel, law faculty, students, and others involved in mining, oil and gas, energy, water, public lands, and related areas of natural resources law. These programs include annual and special institutes<ref>''See'' David E. Pierce, "The Renaissance of ''Law'' in the ''Law of'' Oil and Gas: The Contract Dimension," 42 ''Washburn Law Journal'' 909, 910 (Aug. 27, 2004).</ref> and short courses in various locations around the world.<ref name="rmmlf" />
===Summer Annual Institute=== The Foundation is probably best known for the Annual Institutes and the published ''Proceedings'' containing the scholarly papers presented at each of the Institutes. Annual Institutes were originally held on the campuses of member law schools such as the University of Montana at Missoula, the University of Utah at Salt Lake City, the University of New Mexico at Albuquerque, and the University of Denver.
Institutes today are no longer held on-campus, with the most recent sites including Vancouver, Snowmass, San Francisco, Banff, Santa Fe, and Newport Beach.<ref name="rmmlf" />
===Special Institutes and Short Courses=== The Special Institutes are intended to examine specific topics in depth. Some of the repeating core topics include Mining Agreements, Oil and Gas Agreements, the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), and Federal and Indian Oil and Gas Royalty Valuation and Management.<ref>''See, e.g.,'' Russell Cnty. Sportsmen v. U.S. Forest Serv., 668 F.3d 1037 (9th Cir. 2011) (citing Michael S. Freeman & Meg Parish, "Supplemental NEPA Analyses: Triggers and Requirements," ''National Environmental Policy Act'' 6-1 (Rocky Mt. Min. L. Fdn. 2010)).</ref>
Under the format of a Short Course, an entire field of law is reviewed. Topics have included Mineral Title Examination and Oil and Gas Law. Short Courses on international law are routinely held both in the United States and countries around the world.
==Publications== In addition to institutes and courses, the Foundation publishes a variety of educational materials:
* ''American Law of Mining'' — Mining legal treatise.<ref>''See'' United States v. Good, 257 F. Supp. 2d 1306 (D. Colo. 2003) (citing the ''American Law of Mining'')</ref> * ''Law of Federal Oil and Gas Leases'' — Oil and gas legal treatise.<ref>Rocky Mountain Mineral Law Foundation, Law of Federal Oil and Gas Leases (LexisNexis Matthew Bender)</ref> * ''Landman's Legal Handbook'' — Practical manual for landmen. * ''Annual Proceedings'' — Compilation of papers presented at RMMLF Annual Institutes. * ''Special Institute Materials'' — Papers presented at various Special Institutes. * ''Digital Library''<ref>{{cite web|title=DOI website|url=http://www.doi.gov/library/electronic/rocky-mountain.cfm}}</ref> — Online access to the ''Proceedings'' of the Annual Institutes and papers presented at Special Institutes. * ''Mineral Law Newsletter'' — Current developments in mineral law. * ''Water Law Newsletter'' — Current developments in water law. * ''Gower Federal Services'' — Decisions of the [[Interior Board of Land Appeals]]<ref>Office of Hearings and Appeals, Interior Board of Land Appeals, http://www.oha.doi.gov/about_ibla.htm</ref> and the [[Office of Natural Resources Revenue]]<ref>Office of Natural Resources Revenue, http://www.onrr.gov/</ref> relating to mining, oil and gas, outer continental shelf, and royalty issues. * ''RMMLF Journal'' — Original and reprinted law review articles.
==Outreach==
===Grants=== The Grants Program was established by the Foundation in 1976 to promote scholarship, research, writing, teaching, and the study of mineral resources law and related fields at law schools around the country. Grants awards typically range from $2000 to $5000. Applications are evaluated by the RMMLF Grants Committee, with preference given to the Foundation's Constituent Law Schools and to projects having results of widespread utility and value such as the preparation of teaching materials, publications, and visiting lectureships on mining law, oil and gas law, energy law, water law, public land law and related areas.
===Scholarships=== The Scholarships Program consists of the Joe Rudd Scholarships, established in 1980 in honor of a prominent natural resources attorney in Alaska, and the RMMLF Scholarships, established in 1993. Law students enrolled full-time at one of the Foundation's Constituent Law Schools<ref>{{cite web|title=Lewis and Clark website|url=http://law.lclark.edu/live/news/3749-rocky-mountain-mineral-law-foundation-joe-rudd/law/offices/admissions/news/scholarships/}}</ref> who demonstrate a commitment to the study of natural resources law are eligible to apply for tuition scholarships.<ref>University of Oklahoma College of Law, "Four students awarded national scholarships" (Jan. 23, 2012), http://www.law.ou.edu/blog/four-students-awarded-national-scholarships.</ref> Academic and leadership ability as well as financial need are evaluated by the Foundation's Scholarships Committee consisting of volunteer attorneys. To date, 331 scholarships have been awarded, totaling almost $1.5 million.

revision.text:
{{Politics of Singapore}} The '''Select Committee on Deliberate Online Falsehoods''' is a [[select committee]] of the [[Parliament of Singapore]] that was formed on 11 January 2018 to examine and report on the problem of deliberate online falsehoods and to recommend strategies to deal with them.
The Committee is chaired by Deputy Speaker [[Charles Chong]] and consist of members; Home Affairs and Law Minister [[K Shanmugam]], Senior Minister of State for Communications and Information and for Education [[Janil Puthucheary]], Social and Family Development Minister [[Desmond Lee]], Members of Parliament (MPs) [[Rahayu Mahzam]], Seah Kian Peng, [[Sun Xueling]] and [[Edwin Tong]], as well as Workers' Party MP [[Pritam Singh]] and Nominated Member of Parliament [[Chia Yong Yong]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/select-committee-formed-to-study-deliberate-online-falsehoods-9851096|title=Select Committee formed to study deliberate online falsehoods|publisher=}}</ref>
==Background== On 3 April 2017, Minister of Law K Shanmugam called for a review of existing laws to combat [[fake news]]. He cited the websites ''The Real Singapore'' which published an article claiming that a commotion between Thaipusam participants and the police was sparked by complaints from a Filipino family, the ''States Times Review'' which mocked former President [[S. R. Nathan]] with an article claiming near-zero turnout for his funeral, and ''All Singapore Stuff'' which reported eye-witness account of a collapsed HDB roof at Punggol Waterway Terraces which fooled the police and civil defence to investigate.<ref name="channelnewsasia.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/government--seriously-considering--how-to-deal-with-fake-news-sh-8712436|title=Government ‘seriously considering’ how to deal with fake news: Shanmugam|publisher=}}</ref>
The Minister claimed that fake news, when not debunked, can quickly cause harm to Singaporeans, panic to public, waste emergency resources, and damage reputations of businesses and people. He also claimed that nasty people seek to profit from fake news and that foreign agencies and foreign governments seek to destabilise the government through fake news.<ref name="channelnewsasia.com"/>
During his keynote speech at "Keep It Real: Truth And Trust In The Media" conference on 19 June 2017, Shanmugam said the government has to maintain a strong climate of trust, and be able to counter misinformation spread online. He cited a recent government survey that supported his notion for stronger laws to combat fake news.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/new-laws-fake-news-introduced-2018-shanmugam-053605318.html|title=New laws against fake news to be introduced in 2018: Shanmugam|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reach.gov.sg/~/media/2018/press-release/media-release-on-findings-of-fake-news-poll-26-mar-2018.pdf|title=Findings of Poll on Attitudes towards Fake News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/fake-news-singapore-reach-poll-survey-10077100|title=More than 70% in Singapore have come across fake news online: REACH poll|publisher=}}</ref>
Shanmugam claimed that Singapore has been "particularly vulnerable" to foreign influences via fake news. "If the distrust becomes deep-rooted, people will have serious doubts about the institutions, about leadership, about governance," he said.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/government-economy/shanmugam-law-to-combat-fake-news-to-be-introduced-next-year|title=Shanmugam: Law to combat fake news to be introduced next year|first=Judith|last=Tan|publisher=}}</ref>
On 5 January 2018, the Ministry of Communications and Information (MCI) and Ministry of Law (MinLaw) published a Green Paper titled "Deliberate Online Falsehoods" detailing the need to establish a Select Committee to examine fake news threat in Singapore.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/government-proposes-committee-study-how-deal-deliberate-online-falsehoods|title=Government proposes committee to study how to deal with deliberate online falsehoods|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.mlaw.gov.sg/content/dam/minlaw/corp/News/Annexe%20A%20-%20Green%20Paper%20on%20Deliberate%20Online%20Falsehoods.pdf | title=DELIBERATE ONLINE FALSEHOODS: CHALLENGES AND IMPLICATIONS}}</ref> On 10 January 2018, 80 MPs present voted unanimously in Parliament to appoint a Select Committee of eight PAP MPs, one opposition MP and one NMP to study and report on the problem of deliberate online falsehoods and recommend strategies to deal with them.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/govt-sets-committee-study-problem-deliberate-online-falsehoods|title=Govt sets up committee to study problem of deliberate online falsehoods|publisher=}}</ref>
==Public hearings== The Select Committee convened public hearings from 14 March to 29 March 2018, lasting eight days in total, where 79 individuals and organisations were invited to testify.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/select-committee-on-deliberate-online-falsehoods-79-hearings-10029818|title=Select Committee on deliberate online falsehoods invites 79 for public hearings|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/politics/select-committee-on-deliberate-online-falsehoods-begins-public-hearings-on-wednesday|title=Select Committee on deliberate online falsehoods begins public hearings on Wednesday|first=|last=hermesauto|date=13 March 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
Singaporean historian [[Thum Ping Tjin]] submitted a paper arguing that any legislation by the [[Parliament of Singapore|Singapore Parliament]] against online falsehood must also apply to the [[Government of Singapore|Singapore government]]. He argued that government's use of detention without trial between 1963 and 1988 during [[Operation Coldstore]] and [[Operation Spectrum]]. While the government has stated that the detainees were part of a communist plot or Marxist conspiracy to subvert the state, Thum claimed that the government has never produced any evidence to substantiate its claims nor have any detainees been brought to trial on the charges they were detained under. Thum argued that these justifications were false claims made by politicians of the ruling [[People's Action Party|People's Action Party (PAP)]] for the purpose of political gain.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/submissions-to-the-select-committee-on-deliberate/submission-to-the-select-committee-on-deliberate-online-falsehoods-parliament-of-singapore-984a7a2d6ee3|title=Submission to the Select Committee on Deliberate Online Falsehoods, Parliament of Singapore|last=Thum|first=Ping Tjin|date=2018-02-26|website=Medium|access-date=2018-08-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180629045224/https://medium.com/submissions-to-the-select-committee-on-deliberate/submission-to-the-select-committee-on-deliberate-online-falsehoods-parliament-of-singapore-984a7a2d6ee3|archive-date=29 June 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 29 March, the last day of the sitting of the Select Committee, [[Minister for Law (Singapore)|Law]] and [[Minister for Home Affairs (Singapore)|Home Affairs]] Minister [[K. Shanmugam]] questioned Thum about a paper he published in 2013 regarding Operation Coldstore and the formation of Malaysia''.''<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.academia.edu/5320436/The_Fundamental_Issue_is_Anti-colonialism_Not_Merger_Singapore_s_Progressive_Left_Operation_Coldstore_and_the_Creation_of_Malaysia|title='The Fundamental Issue is Anti-colonialism, Not Merger’: Singapore’s "Progressive Left", Operation Coldstore, and the Creation of Malaysia|first=Pingtjin|last=Thum|publisher=|journal=ARI Working Paper Series}}</ref> He said Thum fell short of the standards of an objective historian, saying that he "ignores evidence which you don't like, you ignore and suppress what is inconvenient and in your writings you present quite an untrue picture".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/historian-thum-ping-tjin-shanmugam-cross-swords-on-singapore-s-10087906|title=Historian Thum Ping Tjin, Shanmugam cross swords on Singapore's communism-related past - Channel NewsAsia<!-- Bot generated title -->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330212300/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/historian-thum-ping-tjin-shanmugam-cross-swords-on-singapore-s-10087906|archive-date=30 March 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=30 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Thum countered that his paper had been peer-reviewed and that no historian had stepped forward to contradict the central thrust of his work.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/shanmugam-historian-thum-ping-tjin-spar-communist-activities-1950s-1960s-123507433.html|title=Shanmugam, historian Thum Ping Tjin spar over communist activities in 1950s-1960s<!-- Bot generated title -->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180412130046/https://sg.news.yahoo.com/shanmugam-historian-thum-ping-tjin-spar-communist-activities-1950s-1960s-123507433.html|archive-date=12 April 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=12 April 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
''[[Channel NewsAsia]]'' and ''[[The Straits Times]]'' reported that Thum admitted that there were parts of the paper which he could have worded better, that some of his statements were misleading, and that he had not read nor bother to quote many of the accounts of some communist leaders as he felt that those accounts were unreliable. These included the first-hand accounts of [[Chin Peng]], the leader of the [[Malayan Communist Party]].<ref>[https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/historian-thum-ping-tjin-shanmugam-cross-swords-on-singapore-s-10087906 Historian Thum Ping Tjin, Shanmugam cross swords on Singapore's communism-related past.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330212300/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/historian-thum-ping-tjin-shanmugam-cross-swords-on-singapore-s-10087906 |date=30 March 2018 }} Channelnewsasia.com</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/politics/shanmugam-grills-research-fellow-and-says-he-is-not-an-objective-historian|title=Minister K. Shanmugam grills research fellow Thum Ping Tjin and says he is not an objective historian|last=hermesauto|date=2018-03-29|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2018-08-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180705025416/https://www.straitstimes.com/politics/shanmugam-grills-research-fellow-and-says-he-is-not-an-objective-historian|archive-date=5 July 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, in a subsequent follow-up submission to the Select Committee, Thum claimed that the reports took his words out of context, arguing that "the crux of my original submission was not addressed in the discussion", "the fundamental arguments... were not raised nor challenged", and "at no point did I accept that any part of my article was inaccurate or misleading". He insisted that "my overall point in my article that [[Operation Coldstore]] was fundamentally motivated by political, not security, reasons, stands".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@pj_85357/follow-up-submission-to-the-select-committee-on-deliberate-online-falsehoods-parliament-of-f1c34a2d9365|title=Follow up Submission to the Select Committee on Deliberate Online Falsehoods, Parliament of…|last=Thum|first=Pingtjin|date=2018-05-03|website=Medium|access-date=2018-08-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180506152652/https://medium.com/@pj_85357/follow-up-submission-to-the-select-committee-on-deliberate-online-falsehoods-parliament-of-f1c34a2d9365|archive-date=6 May 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Reactions == Civil activists groups Community Action Network, Function 8, and ''Maruah'', as well as activists Kirsten Han, [[The Online Citizen|Terry Xu]], and Thum himself, criticised the open hearings, accusing the Select Committee of failing to adhere to its own terms of reference, and claiming the hearings had not been conducted in an open or consultative manner.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://singaporecan.wordpress.com/2018/04/02/civil-society-activists-criticise-singapores-select-committee-hearings/|title=Civil society activists criticise Singapore’s Select Committee hearings|date=2018-04-02|work=Community Action Network, Singapore|access-date=2018-08-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180728223334/https://singaporecan.wordpress.com/2018/04/02/civil-society-activists-criticise-singapores-select-committee-hearings/|archive-date=28 July 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/select-committee-to-look-into-complaints-on-public-hearings-10100610|title=Select Committee to look into complaints on public hearings: Charles Chong|work=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/maruah-slams-select-committees-confrontational-stance|title=Maruah slams Select Committee’s ‘confrontational stance’|work=TODAYonline|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref>
A letter signed by 170 academics was submitted to Chong, criticising the hearing as an attempt to attack and destroy Thum's credibility and discredit his research, with the effect of stifling the freedom of expression and academic freedom in Singapore.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/politics/thum-ping-tjins-submission-a-political-piece-and-he-must-expect-to-be-questioned-about-its|title=Thum Ping Tjin must expect to be questioned, says Charles Chong in response to open letter by academics|last=hermesauto|date=2018-04-17|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2018-08-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180424225914/https://www.straitstimes.com/politics/thum-ping-tjins-submission-a-political-piece-and-he-must-expect-to-be-questioned-about-its|archive-date=24 April 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20180515163318165|title=Academic freedom faces 'grave threat' from parliament - University World News|website=www.universityworldnews.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180515211935/http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20180515163318165|archive-date=15 May 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=2018-08-22|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A letter from six of Thum's colleagues at the University of Oxford's Project Southeast Asia also expressed concerns about how Thum was treated at the hearing, saying that Thum's research, which Shanmugam had criticised, had "already met the rigorous standards of examination at Oxford and peer review by fellow historical experts on the region". The letter also expressed concerns about the "implications for academic freedom, and for freedom of expression in Singapore", saying that the hearing "appears designed to intimidate those who seek to publish the truth".<ref name=":0" />
In response, Chong argued that it was Thum who had chosen to make a political point in his written submission to the Select Committee, and that while Thum was entitled to his views, he must expect to be questioned about his claims.<ref name=":1" /> He also characterised Thum's submission as a "political piece" rather than an "academic dissertation".<ref name=":1" />
Chong also released a report based upon attached emails between two trustees of Project Southeast Asia that were inadvertently copied to the Select Committee, showing email discussions between Thum and Philip Kreager from the University of Oxford's Project Southeast Asia regarding the drafting and sharing of a letter in support of Thum.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/historian-thum-ping-tjin-appears-to-be-involved-in-coordinated-attempt-to-subvert|title=Historian Thum Ping Tjin appears to be involved in coordinated attempt to subvert parliamentary processes: Charles Chong|first=|last=hermesauto|date=30 April 2018|publisher=}}</ref> Chong accused Thum of having "engineered" the open letter in support of himself, as well as getting Kraeger to canvass for support on his behalf.<ref name=":3" /> Chong alleged "a coordinated attempt, with foreign actors involved, to try to influence and subvert our parliamentary processes".<ref name=":3" /> Kreager called Chong's statement "clearly preposterous", insisting that the emails were merely to "exchange views", and accusing Chong of imagining a "conspiracy".<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/allegations-conspiring-historian-thum-subvert-parliamentary-processes-preposterous-oxford|title=Allegations of conspiring with historian Thum to subvert parliamentary processes ‘preposterous’: Oxford academic|work=TODAYonline|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref>
On 13 April, the [[Parliament of Singapore#Parliament Secretariat|Parliament Secretariat]] wrote to Thum to clarify his academic credentials following his claims to be a "research fellow in history" in his submission and holding "a visiting professorship in anthropology at Oxford University" during his oral testimony. Following media enquiries, the University of Oxford replied that Thum was a research associate at the School of Anthropology and Museum Ethnography.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/politics/thum-ping-tjin-is-research-associate-with-anthropology-school-oxford |title=Thum Ping Tjin is research associate with anthropology school: Oxford, Politics News & Top Stories - The Straits Times<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=1 May 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180501235409/https://www.straitstimes.com/politics/thum-ping-tjin-is-research-associate-with-anthropology-school-oxford |archive-date=1 May 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
